title: 110_hr4218
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Diabetes Self-Management Training Act of 2007". Congress finds that diabetes is a major public health threat in the US, with millions affected and increasing prevalence. Diabetes self-management training is crucial for patients to learn necessary skills and overcome barriers. Diabetes self-management training is essential for patients to overcome barriers and effectively manage their condition. Certified diabetes educators, such as nurses, dietitians, or pharmacists, specialize in helping patients develop the necessary skills to stay healthy and avoid complications. Studies have shown that this training can reduce the risks and complications associated with diabetes. Lifestyle changes, including those taught by certified diabetes educators, can significantly reduce the risk of developing type 2 diabetes by up to 58%. These changes are particularly effective in individuals aged 60 and older, with a 71% reduction in diabetes development. Patients under the care of a certified diabetes educator show improved glycemic control and reduced complications, with the potential to prevent serious medical issues such as blindness, amputations, and heart problems by up to 90%, 85%, and 50% respectively. There are over 20,000 certified diabetes educators in the US who must meet specific qualifications and pass a national exam to maintain their certification. Diabetes educators certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators and licensed by a State are qualified to provide diabetes self-management training under Medicare. Certified diabetes educators recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are now recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. The term 'certified diabetes educator' refers to an individual licensed or registered as a healthcare professional in the state where services are provided, specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition, and certified by a recognized certifying body. The term 'recognized certifying body' for certified diabetes educators includes the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators or a certifying body recognized by the Secretary to grant certification. The Board or body must be incorporated and registered in the US and require certification with a qualifying credential, professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training, completion of a national certification examination, and periodic renewal of certification status. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services. A report on the study must be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The Director of AHRQ will develop recommendations for outreach methods and report on them. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations on effective outreach methods for educating primary care physicians and the public about diabetes self-management training. A report on these recommendations must be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The Act requires that furnished items must be provided at least 6 months after the enactment date.
